NEWS BITES

U.S. Loan Refinancing Picks Up as Mortgage Rates Drop Again U.S. 30-year fixed mortgage rates dropped by eight basis points to 3.57% week-over-week as of Oct. 10, according to Freddie Mac. And 15-year fixed-rate mortgages also dropped during the same time period by nine basis points to 3.05%. The continued drop in rates has created a 163% year-over-year rise in refinancing activity, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. MarketWatch

New Brexit Deal Optimism Causes Jump in U.K. Housebuilders and Bank Shares After Prime Minister Boris Johanson and Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar met and decided a Brexit deal is possible by the end of the month, optimism caused housebuilder and bank shares to rise. Galliford Try jumped by 9.2% and the Royal Bank of Scotland rose 7.3%. A seamless trade between the EU and the U.K. would benefit all sectors, said Michael Hewson, chief market analyst for CMC Markets. City A.M.

Mini Boom Hits Australia’s Housing Market New home loans in Australia rose 3.2% in August from the month before to A$33.5 billion (US$22.7 billion), according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Property investor lending also increased by 6%, making its biggest jump since Sept. 2016. The signs of upbeat housing activity are expected to boost consumer confidence and spurn a mini-boom in the market, said UBS economist George Tharenou. Business Times

A California Town in San Diego County Is Put on the Market Las Vegas investor John Ray put much of Campo, California’s historic town center up for sale. Campo is a rural hamlet with an Old West feel an hour from downtown San Diego and an hour from the U.S.-Mexico border. The sale includes 28 residences in the 16-acre village. The town was last put up for sale in 1994 for $1.75 million. Los Angeles Times

Realtors Remain Wary as Canadian Candidates Promise to Re-Ignite Home Prices Canada’s already high home prices are expected to rise 1.5% in the fourth quarter over the same time last year without any policy changes, but Canada’s candidates are pledging new home-buyer incentives that could raise prices without addressing supply issues, according to Royal LePage. As well-intentioned candidates focus on making home buying more affordable for first-time buyers, they could trigger a surge without increasing the supply, said Phil Soper, president and chief executive officer of Royal LePage. Vancouver Sun

Hong Kong Property Group Asks Government to Issue Land Bonds for Housing Crisis The Hong Kong Real Property Federation will meet with Hong Kong’s government to propose that land bonds are issued to private landowners in order to speed up rural development to help alleviate the city’s housing crisis. The city’s shortage of land is primarily blamed for rising property prices. South China Morning Post
